g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
At the beginning of the simulation, there are 39 students in the ofﬁce, i.e., one infected student (
). They touch surfaces and talk with each other based on realistic
data on surface touch and interpersonal contacts obtained fromthe video analysis. In each simulation,
all students will select an action, such as with surfaces they touch and with whomthey talk, fromthe
database (collected surface touch and close contact data) at each time step (second).
Particles of various sizes ae generated by activities such as breathing, talking, coughing and
m) uniformly ﬂoated in the air of the ofﬁce.
The deposition of these small particles is slight because it requires around an hour in a steady
]. In an ofﬁce setting, the deposition rate will be reduced because of frequent
walking by the students. We assumed that the deposition rate was 0.1 min
of the particles’ volume is deposited uniformly on all surfaces per minute.
Because the difference in the association between the size and number of particles fromprevious
researchers is large, we use the average values fromprevious studies to assess the total virus quantity
in small particles. Summarising the previous studies [
], the total volume of small particles
) (counting from 1 to 100, which takes about 100 s),
mL, respectively. The total volume of large particles (
mL, respectively. Here, we assumed that the size distribution of
particles generated by coughing and sneezing was the same. People take an average of 15 breaths
per minute, so a breath takes around 4 s [
]. The average frequencies of coughing and sneezing
episodes for an inﬂuenza A infected person are 22/h [
1 s, and a sneeze is assumed to take 3 s. Our recorded data show that students in the ofﬁce spent an
average of 10%of their time talking with others. Therefore, the frequency of breathing (
) of an infected person are 21,600 times, 0.8 h (two students on average
share the time during talking), 352 times and 80 times per day (talking, coughing and sneezing during
16 h except 8-h sleep). The total volume of droplets generated by an infected person per day (
= 1 to 4 shows the human activities of breathing, talking, coughing and sneezing, respectively;
are the total volume of small and large droplets generated by an infected person per
We assumed that an infected person’s initial viral shedding rate is around
], and it changes with time and the severity of infection.
Because the amount of virus in a particle is roughly proportional to the particle’s volume [
we considered the virus concentrations in all particles to be the same. The virus concentration (
in all particles is then obtained (
TCID50/mL). This value is between the virus
) in ofﬁces is usually set to 1 ACH [
) of inﬂuenza A in aerosols in the
air changes with the relative humidity (RH%) and temperature [
humidity and temperature in the ofﬁce were around 50% and 20
) of inﬂuenza A in aerosols in the air is 13.9 day
